children.subject:
Briefly summarize, it’s not that necessary to take the course as soon as possible if you are not eager to gain some experience on the whole lifecycle of data science projects. Some people would say a stat course with cs 188 would teach you far more than what you would learn from data 100, but it depends.
Btw, in case if you are interested in pandas, data 100 would also teach pandas of python, a package that works similarly to R in statistics (just similar).
CS 188 is not a practical class at all (for AI/ML in industry). I'd say take 127, 189.

cs 189's prereq includes math 54—which I haven't taken and I haven't taken ee16b either (will take it next spring). do you think I could still take cs 189 at all? I heard someone say 189 doesn't involve that much of math 54 content but I'm not too sure abt that.
also people seem pretty split on taking cs 188. if 188 isn't too practical for industry, is there some other benefit in taking that class?

I sort of agree that 188 isn’t that practical, but that doesn’t mean that it’s totally meaningless. 
It’s like a general survey on current topics in Al, which means if you took courses covering all those subtopics (say 182+189), they would approximately cover the same content in a greater depth. The meaning of taking 188 IMO is like getting an overview of Al fields, get familiar to what you are going to endure in 189, and gain some unique perspectives from Prof teaching this course.
If the course list were already very constraint, it would be worthy skipping 188 and jump directly to 189.

188 also covers a lot of non-ML material that you're not going to learn in 182 or 189, so 182 + 189 does not replace 188. In fact I'd argue that 188 does nothing to prepare you for 189—doesn't even give you a snapshot of how difficult 189 might be—because the 188 ML material is very light on math, whereas 189 is heavy on the math. Not that 188 isn't important—ML isn't everything in AI—but if you're focused only on ML then you can definitely skip 188.

As for the Math 54/EECS 16b requirement, that's just linear algebra, which you can also learn in 127. Doing 127 and then 189 the next semester will be more than enough for the linear algebra aspect.
Thanks for the correction of my response above! I am kind of being taken away by the overemphasis of 189 these days...

In my personal opinion (may not be right), data 8 is not that necessary but the renewed data 100 is requiring it as a prereq. Nonetheless, this is subject to change in the future when other departments are in charge of the instruction of data 100. The basic meaning of data 100 is give you a brief stretch of ML topics like optimization and regression, which you could learn deeper in 127 and 189. Another point for taking 100 is that t would provide a series of projects similar to real-work situation of data processing, which could build up hand-on experiences.

I'll add that it's not just likely that they'll enforce the prereq in the future, but they've committed to absolutely enforcing the prereq (with the exception of some substitution stat classes; see https://piazza.com/class/j7s01y165odq5?cid=3614 if you've joined the Data 001 piazza)

I am not a Stat major, so I cannot comment on Stat 15x courses, which I did not take.

Data 100 coding are not difficult but very rewarding from my perspective because it is kind of different from other CS upper division courses. If you would like to learn how to process data in Python, definitely take Data 100. 

Two things to notice:

First, Data 8 reserve seats for freshman and sophomore, and is hard to get into for junior and senior.

Second, in the future semesters, data science department will likely enforce Data 8 prerequisite for Data 100.

From my friends I heard that Data 8 is pretty light, so in my opinion adding Data 8 in one of your future two semesters shouldn't break your plans. I also heard that Stat upper division courses like 151A+153+154 combo cover lots of things that is covered in Data 100, but uses R.

history.content:
If you're interested in ML, prioritized taking 189/188/182 as soon as possible.

--------

Coming from a perspective of a person fresh into ML (no fancy math background and the like), I think Data 100 should be taken before CS 189 for a good sense of whether or not you will like the concepts of CS 189 or not, since the last half of the class is Machine Learning on a surface level.

I would say the same for Data 8 tho.

If you're interested in ML, prioritized taking 189/188/182 as soon as possible.

--------

Coming from a perspective of a person fresh into ML (no fancy math background and the like), I think Data 100 should be taken before CS 189 for a good sense of whether or not you will like the concepts of CS 189 or not, since the last half of the class is Machine Learning on a surface level.

Not so much Data 8 tho.
If you're interested in ML, prioritized taking 189/188/182 as soon as possible.

I am a rising sophomore interested in AI/ML & I originally planned to take Data 8 & 100 in my two sophomore semesters, but due to a change in my plans it looks like I might have to push back taking them until my junior year (even though I don't want to b/c I thought taking them would be useful). Is it better to take the Data courses as early as possible (i.e., does it have any benefits or whatnot), or is it okay to kind of take them later?
history.subject: Data 8 & Data 100
